awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Laboratory and Theoretical Investigations of the Micro-Mechanical Origins of Rate and State Friction on Tectonic Faults
awd_abstract_narration:
In the earthquake-cycle, tectonic faults slowly accumulate stress, due to plate tectonic motion of Earth?s surface, and then fail catastrophically in earthquakes.  One of the keys to simulating the earthquake cycle are friction laws that can be applied to both the fast, dynamic motion of earthquakes, as fault rocks rub and slide past one another in frictional contact, and the slow processes of stress accumulation between earthquakes that can take hundreds of years. In this collaborative work between Princeton and Penn State Universities, unusually well-controlled measurements of frictional sliding will be conducted while collecting simultaneous ultrasonic data on the sliding interfaces and sheared layers of fault gouge. The proposed work has important societal implications for seismic hazard assessment, earthquake forecasting, and an improved, fundamental understanding of earthquake nucleation.

Rate-and-state friction laws represent the current state-of-the-art in the laboratory and for numerical simulations of earthquake physics, including nucleation, dynamic rupture and the complete seismic cycle.  However, our understanding of friction memory effects and slip velocity dependence remains primarily empirical, which limits our ability to apply laboratory measurements to earthquake faults and/or to address the problems associated with predicting the behavior of tectonic faults from laboratory measurements.  To address these shortcomings, recent advances in ultrasonic monitoring of sliding rock surfaces and sheared granular fault gouge will provide fundamental insights into the physics and micro-mechanical origins of frictional behavior of tectonic faults.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research: Laboratory and Theoretical Investigations of the Micro-Mechanical Origins of Rate and State Friction on Tectonic Faults

C. Marone (Penn State University) A. Rubin (Princeton University)

 Our understanding of rock friction and fracture is now at the stage that we can simulate the earthquake-cycle in which tectonic faults slowly accumulate stress, due to plate tectonic motion of Earth’s surface, and then fail catastrophically in earthquakes.  One of the keys to simulating the earthquake cycle are friction laws that can be applied to both the fast, dynamic motion of earthquakes, as fault rocks rub and slide past one another in frictional contact, and the slow processes of stress accumulation between earthquakes that can take hundreds of years. The friction laws are based on laboratory and theoretical work, and there have been significant advances over the past 40 years or so. Rate and state friction laws represent the current state of the art in the laboratory and for numerical simulations of earthquake physics, including nucleation, dynamic rupture and the complete seismic cycle.  However, despite significant progress in illuminating the underlying physics of these laws, much work has remained.  In particular, our understanding of friction memory effects (dictated primarily via the friction state term) and slip velocity dependence (determined by the rate terms) remains rudimentary, which limits our ability to apply lab measurements to earthquake faults and/or to address the problems associated with predicting the behavior of tectonic faults, at field scale, from laboratory measurements made on sample sizes measured in mm or cm. 

This research addressed these shortcomings. In particular, we used ultrasonic waves to image frictional sliding between rock surfaces and within granular fault gouge.  Our work focused on the micro-mechanical processes that underlie rate and state friction. We conducted the work collaboratively with colleagues at Princeton University. The Penn State work involved unusually-well controlled measurements of frictional sliding while collecting simultaneous ultrasonic data in the form of elastic waves that traveled through the sliding interfaces. The work accomplished includes data while the fault was sliding under conditions far from steady state, which is both geologically relevant and provided a more stringent test of existing friction laws than previous works. The work accomplished for this project went well beyond existing studies because we were able to use both P- and S-wave measurements and because we studied conditions further from steady state, by looking at both bare rock surfaces and granular fault gouge, and by obtaining higher-resolution data than existing works. The data collected for this project provide fundamental insights into the physics and micro-mechanical origins of rate and state frictional behavior of tectonic faults. They are also improving our ability to model the behavior of earthquake faults. Finally, this work funded by the National Science Foundation has important societal implications because of seismic hazard assessment, earthquake forecasting, and an improved, fundamental understanding of earthquake nucleation. 

Our work is described in a number of publications, including the following.  Most of these are freely available.  Anyone who would like access to others should contact Chris Marone at marone@psu.edu

Hulbert, C., Rouet-Leduc, B., Johnson, P. A., Ren, C. X., Rivière, J., Bolton, D. C., and C. Marone (2019). Machine learning predictions illuminate similarity of fast and slow laboratory earthquakes. Nat. Geosc., 12, 69-74, 10.1038/s41561-018-0272-8. 

Im, Kyungjae, Marone, C. and D. Elsworth (2019). The transition from steady frictional sliding to inertia-dominated instability with rate and state friction. J. Mech. Phys. Sol., 122, 116-125, 10.1016/j.jmps.2018.08.026. 

Kenigsberg, A. R., Rivière, J., Marone, C. and D. M. Saffer, (2019). The effects of shear strain, fabric, and porosity evolution on elastic and mechanical properties of clay-rich fault gouge. J. Geophys. Res. Solid Earth, 10.1029/2019JB017944. 

Kenigsberg, A. R., Rivière, J., Marone, C. and D. M. Saffer, (2020). Evolution of elastic and mechanical properties during fault shear: the roles of clay content, fabric development, and porosity. J. Geophys. Res. Solid Earth, 10.1029/2019JB018612

Lyu, Z., Rivière, J., Yang, Q., and C. Marone (2019). On the mechanics of granular shear: the effect of normal stress and layer thickness on stick-slip properties. Tectonophysics, 10.1016/j.tecto.2019.04.010.

Schwartz, B., Elsworth, D., and C. Marone (2019). Relationships between mechanical and transport properties in Marcellus shale. Int. J. Rock Mech. and Min. Sci., 119, 205–210, 10.1016/j.ijrmms.2019.04.020. 

Shreedharan, S., Rivière, J., Bhattacharya, P., and C. Marone (2019). Frictional state evolution during normal stress perturbations probed with ultrasonic waves. Geophys. Res. Solid Earth, 124, 1-23, 10.1029/2018JB016885. 

Yassaghi, A. and C. Marone (2019). The relationship between fault zone structure and frictional heterogeneity, insight from faults in the High Zagros. Tectonophysics, 762, 109– 120, 10.1016/j.tecto.2019.04.029.

Zhu, T., Ajo-Franklin, J. Daley, T., M. and C. Marone (2019). Dynamics of geologic CO2 storage and plume motion revealed by seismic coda waves. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci, 10.1073/pnas.1810903116.
